bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, June 9, 1953

div1.p: Tate sends Truby his analysis of the checkbook stubs. He found it intriguing and wants Truby to see his results in case they highlight something Truby might have overlooked or help to verify his findings.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, June 9, 1953
div1.opener:
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley 3, California
June 9, 1953
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, Calif.
Dear General Truby:
div1.p:
Oh, there wasn't anything serious in your letter I referred
to. You merely said, “Don't write anything about it until
you see my effort.” So, as an old soldier, I obeyed my C.O. 's
request!

Mainly
tried to save
time for you

Mine is no story of it, for I know nothing of Camp Lazear
personally, but I saw a new light regarding various things
there from reading these check-book stubs. So I was intrigued
into breaking it up into its integral parts and seeing what
it meant.

I wished you to see this break-down, not because there would
be anything important in it that you have not already dis-
covered, but it might have some insignificent point you have
overlooked, or, verify some of your findings.

Of course, with your greater knowledge you have probably
found items that meant nothing to me, and some of mine may
be entirely wrong. For lack of any further original autho-
rity, I am just guessing.

Anyhow, I am enclosing my “look-see” Needless to say, I
await with anticipation your version of what happened there.
I know it will be the correct one, and take some of the
guessing out of my notes.
